Can somebody with deeper #technical knowledge of Mastodon/#ActivityPub help me understand how information is moved around?

My very limited understanding is that when a user publishes/sends a post, the message is first put into the user's "outbox" located on the user's instance. It is then pulled from there from all the instances his/her followers are located on.

In order to receive posts, the user's instance continuously checks all the outboxes a user is subscribed to and pulls the messages located there, into the user's "inbox".

The federated timeline would then be the sum of all the messages that the local instance has pulled from the various outboxes its users are subscribed to.

To create the local timeline, the local instance pulls messages from all the local outboxes.

A user's individual timeline is simply the list of all the messages that are put into his/her outbox.

That would be the default. Users can shape how their posts are pulled by changing the post's privacy setting.

Defederation then works by no longer pulling from a specific instance and not allowing that instance to pull messages from the local instance thus blocking all direct communication.

https://github.com/w3c/activitypub/blob/gh-pages/activitypub-tutorial.txt

title: GitHub - asiekierka/almost-of-zzt: (Almost) development backup of ZZT's original source code.

last_post.content:
According to Tim Sweeney, the original ZZT source code was lost in the early 90s: "[... If] I had it, I'd release it, but I lost it in a crash a long time ago."

But they were all of them deceived, for another backup was made.

This is an (almost) unaltered copy of the actual ZZT ~3.0 source code - not decompiled, not reverse-engineered, but preserved for its historical value.

You wouldn't believe me if I told you how many years I spent looking for it, after catching wind of where it might be... For three decades, the ZZT community hoped it would turn up. For two, it thought it was impossible. And yet, here we are.

I'm really happy to have been able to contribute to the ZZT community's preservation efforts for all these years. Thank you. This is probably my magnum opus.

https://github.com/asiekierka/almost-of-zzt

title: Fix poetry pip-shims extras dependency by jooola · Pull Request #2078 · PyCQA/isort

last_post.content:
Got lots of repos to update?

You can use all-repos-sed with something like this:

all-repos-sed --dry-run --commit-msg $"Bump isort to fix Poetry\n\nRe: https://github.com/PyCQA/isort/pull/2078" 's~rev: 5\.1.\..~rev: 5.12.0~g' -- '.pre-commit-config.yaml'

Remove --dry-run to create PRs, after checking the regex is working fine for you.

Setup instructions:

https://jugmac00.github.io/blog/how-to-create-hundreds-of-pull-requests-with-a-single-command/

#isort failing on #CI in #precommit in with this?

[extras.pipfile_deprecated_finder.2] 'pip-shims<=0.3.4' does not match '^[a-zA-Z-_.0-9]+$'

It's fixed in https://github.com/PyCQA/isort/pull/2078, bump your isort to 5.12.0.

Update with:

pre-commit autoupdate

Or:

pre-commit autoupdate --repo https://github.com/PyCQA/isort

Interesting approach from the @sklearn project:

You can install via "pip install scikit-learn", but they have an old "sklearn" package on PyPI that they want to deprecate, so they released sklearn with a brownout schedule, where it will fail to install between certain times.

And the time windows for failures will increase.

Did you see a failure? Replace "sklearn" with "scikit-learn" in your dependencies.

More info: https://github.com/scikit-learn/sklearn-pypi-package #python #scikitlearn #sklearn #deprecation
